author: RT
title: ‘Medieval barbarism’: Riga mayor decries fine for use of Russian on official Facebook account
text:
‘Medieval barbarism’: Riga mayor decries fine for use of Russian on official Facebook account   21:51 Get short URL Riga's city major Nils Usakovs © Ints Kalnins / Reuters The mayor of the Latvian capital Riga, has hit out at the Baltic country’s State Language Center (VVC) after being fined for posting in Russian on Facebook. 
On Monday, Nils Usakovs, took to the social media platform to condemn the center and its policies, which he described as “medieval savagery”. 
“The Latvian State Language Center launches an investigation why the mayor of Riga, when asked a question by Russian-speaking children, answered them in Russian,” Usakovs wrote . 
“The spokesperson for the State Language Center publically states that the Mayor of Riga, even on his own personal Facebook profile, can write only in Latvian,” Usakovs continued. Read more Mayor promotes Riga as ‘Meldonium Home City’ amid widening doping scandal 
“This medieval barbarism along the lines of ‘a mayor cannot answer a Russian child in Russian’ is, putting it mildly, incomprehensible. Not to me, I’m long used to the VVC. But to those children who, in the opinion of the VVC, can only ask questions in their native language outside working hours.” 
Usakovs compared the government’s stance towards languages to the Soviet regime and blamed the VVC’s position on the tight political grip of the nationalist parties. 
“Latvia spends her last money on defense and loves every platoon of allied soldiers that comes by. But our nation will never be safe while right-wing parties in Latvia continue their current policies towards the Russian-speaking residents of the country.” 
Usakovs noted that British Foreign Minister Boris Johnson, during his tenure as mayor of London, called on Londoners to celebrate Maslenitsa in Russian, while the official website of Berlin has information in German, English, French, Italian, Chinese, Polish, Russian and Turkish languages. Even the NATO homepage has information in Russian, in addition to English, French, and Ukrainian. 
Latvia, as a former Soviet republic, has a large Russian-speaking minority, with about 37 percent of the people considering Russian their primary language. For some of them, like small children in Russian families, Russian is the only language they can speak well. 
However, Latvian is legally the only official language in the country, and passing a language test is mandatory in order to receive full citizenship. Hundreds of thousands of ethnic Russians living in Latvia are languishing as “non-citizens”, ineligible to vote or take public office. 
Last year, Usakovs and his City Hall were fined €140 ($148) for posting information in both Latvian and Russian on his official social media account. Read more Diplomacy skulls: Riga mayor mocks official fine for using Russian language on Facebook 
“If we talk about the essence of social networking, it is a form of remote communication,” VVC representative Viesturs Razumovskis told the BBC's Russian service. “With respect to the Latvian or foreign social networks it does not matter, what information the municipality gives, but whether it is given at all. And if we are talking about information from the government, it must be in the state language.” 
Usakovs appealed the decision which was upheld by the Riga District Court, but signaled that he intends to appeal again. Latvia’s State Language Law mandates that both local and national governments may only use the official state language for informing the public, with a few exceptional cases. 
“It is clear what the law requires, but also from a human point of view, if we want to engage people among us who speak a foreign language, for instance, Russian-speakers,” Delfi reported Ingrida Berzins, Deputy Director of VVC, as saying. “We are not just helping them integrate, we are paving the way for [full] integration.” 
Usakovs is the leader of the center-left Harmony party, which represents the interests of Russian speakers in Latvia. In the 2014 parliamentary elections, Harmony won 23.1 percent of the vote, the most of any other party, but was kept out of power by a coalition of the three runners up – Unity, National Alliance and the Union of Greens and Farmers.
